Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Field Mobile Soil Nitrate Sensor for Precision Fertilizer Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project stems from the need to substantially improve nitrogen (N) use efficiency in crop production and thereby improve profitability for farmers, while simultaneously reducing the adverse effects of agriculture on the environment. Currently, less than half of the N fertilizer applied to agricultural fields is used by the crops to which it is applied. The remaining N is either leached from the soil or lost to the atmosphere as nitrous oxide - potent greenhouse gas. This inefficient use of N fertilizer by crops is an economic burden for farmers, cause serious water and air quality problems, and contribute about 2.5% of total U.S. greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, these N losses represent a tremendous energy inefficiency, because the production of synthetic N fertilizer is the largest energy input in production agriculture. The key to improving N use efficiency in crop production is applying the right amount of N fertilizer in the right place at the right time. The proposed sensor technology would be disruptive to existing agricultural technology and practices, wherein N fertilizer is applied at a uniform rate across agricultural fields, and improve profitability for farmers.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of a robust field-mobile soil nitrate (NO3-) sensor utilizing mid-infrared technology to facilitate precision N fertilizer applications. Mid-infrared spectrometers have historically been large, expensive, and fragile laboratory instruments that require substantial sample preparation, thus preventing their use as mobile optical soil NO3- sensors. The scope of the Phase I research will focus on three objectives: 1) The design and development of a robust and low-cost mid-infrared spectrometer that uses a diamond attenuated total internal reflectance (D-ATR) probe to measure NO3- levels; 2) The design, construction, and testing of a chisel shank-tool bar system that houses the spectrometer and D-ATR probe; and 3) the development of control and data processing and analysis software to manage the system. Anticipated technical results of Phase I will provide a prototype that can measure NO3- in the upper 30 cm of soil, not just at the surface, by enabling modulation of the depth of the shank and the probe as the system is pulled through a field, and self-cleaning of the system as soil is continuously moved across the optical surface of the diamond by the forward motion of the tractor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
N-Sense is developing a low-cost, robust infrared spectrometer-based sensor system that can be attached to a fertilizer applicator and used to continuously measure soil nitrate levels. This novel technology is designed to allow a fertilizer applicator’s control system to modulate in-season nitrogen fertilizer application rates in real-time as the applicator moves through a field. The N-Sense soil nitrate sensor system has the potential to replace the current soil-sampling protocol that is done by hand and that most farmers consider impractical.  Currently, less than half of the nitrogen fertilizer applied to agricultural fields is actually used by the crops to which it is applied.  The remaining nitrogen is either leached from the soil, polluting surface and groundwater, or emitted to the atmosphere as nitrogen gas (harmless) or nitrous oxide (a potent greenhouse gas). These nitrogen fertilizer losses are an economic burden for farmers, cause serious water quality problems, and contribute about 2.5% of total U.S. greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, these nitrogen losses represent a tremendous energy inefficiency, because the production of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer is by far the largest energy input in production agriculture. The proposed sensor technology will result in substantial savings in nitrogen fertilizer costs due to the sensor’s ability to facilitate the precision placement of N fertilizer.  It will reduce the wasteful application of N fertilizers and their negative impact on water and air quality.

The overall goal of the NSF SBIP Phase I project was to design, build and test a prototype of a field-mobile soil nitrate sensing system and demonstrate the feasibility of utilizing the sensor under field conditions. Our long-term goal is to integrate our sensors with fertilizer applicators to allow farmers to measure soil nitrate levels while precisely applying nitrogen fertilizer during a single pass through a field.

During the Phase I NSF SBIR project we designed, built, and tested a prototype of our field mobile soil nitrate sensor system.  We developed a chisel implement that houses the sensor system, software to control the sensor system, and a proprietary algorithm to predict soil nitrate concentrations from collected spectra.  We also greatly expanded our calibration database to include well over one thousand samples. In addition to developing sensor technology, we conducted extensive customer discovery interviews both before and as part of the NSF SBIR Phase I Program. The customer discovery research and corporate outreach activities have been extremely valuable in helping us to understand the needs and interests of our customers, refine our business model, and build corporate relationships that are critical to our future commercial success.

The development and widespread commercial deployment of our proposed soil nitrate-sensor technology is anticipated to substantially improve N use efficiency in crop production (reduce N fertilizer use by 10% to 50%, depending on soil, climate, and management) and to thereby improve profitability for farmers, while simultaneously reducing the adverse effects of agriculture on the environment.  Building a successful prototype of the nitrate sensor was a major step on the path towards commercialization.
